{{DISPLAYTITLE:{{mp|2001 AV|43}}}} {{Infobox planet | minorplanet = yes | background = #FFC2E0 | name = {{mp|2001 AV|43}} | image = | caption = | discovery_ref =   | discoverer = [[Lincoln Near-Earth Asteroid Research|LINEAR]] | discovery_site = {{nowrap|[[Lincoln Laboratory's Experimental Test Site|Lincoln Laboratory ETS]]}} | discovered = 5 January 2001 | mpc_name = {{mp|2001 AV|43}} | mp_category = [[Near-Earth object|NEO]]{{·}}[[List of Apollo asteroids|Apollo]]  | pronounced = | named_after = | alt_names = | orbit_ref =   | epoch = 27 April 2019 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2458600.5) | uncertainty = 0 | observation_arc = 13.23 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (4,834 d) | aphelion = 1.5929 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] | perihelion = 0.9744 AU | semimajor = 1.2836 AU | eccentricity = 0.2409 | period = 1.45 yr (531 d) | mean_anomaly = 256.05[[Degree (angle)|°]] | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.6777|sup=ms}} / day | inclination = 0.2013° | asc_node = 20.505° | arg_peri = 51.311° | moid = 0.0017 AU{{·}}0.66 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|LD]] | mean_diameter = {{val|0.03|ul=km}} {{small|(derived)}} | rotation = {{val|0.1701|ul=h}} {{small|(612 [[Second|s]])}} | albedo = 0.20 {{small|(assumed)}} | spectral_type = [[S-type asteroid|S]] {{small|(assumed)}} | abs_magnitude = 24.6
24.9 }} '''{{mp|2001 AV|43}}''' is a very small, monolithic [[asteroid]] and [[List of fast rotators (minor planets)|fast rotator]], classified as a [[near-Earth object]] of the [[Apollo asteroid|Apollo group]], approximately {{convert|30|m|ft|abbr=off|sp=us}} in diameter. It was first observed on 5 January 2001, by astronomers of the [[Lincoln Near-Earth Asteroid Research|LINEAR]] program at [[Lincoln Laboratory's Experimental Test Site]] near Socorro, New Mexico, in the United States. The presumed [[S-type asteroid]] has an [[rotation period]] of only 10 minutes. It has an exceptionally low [[minimum orbital intersection distance|MOID]] of 0.66 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|lunar distance]] (LD) and will approach Earth at 0.81 LD on 11 November 2029. == Orbit and classification == {{mp|2001 AV|43}} is a member of the dynamical [[Apollo asteroid|Apollo group]], which are [[Earth-crossing asteroid]]s. Apollo asteroids are the largest subgroup of [[near-Earth object]]s. Unlike many Apollo asteroids, this asteroid is not a [[Mars-crosser]], as its [[aphelion]] is smaller than the orbit of the Red Planet at 1.66 [[Astronomical unit|AU]]. This asteroid orbits the Sun at a distance of 0.97–1.59 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] once every 17 months (531 days; [[semi-major axis]] of 1.28 AU). Its orbit has an [[orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] of 0.24 and an [[orbital inclination|inclination]] of 0[[Degree (angle)|°]] with respect to the [[ecliptic]]. The body's [[observation arc]] begins with a [[precovery]] found in [[European Southern Observatory|ESO]]'s [[Astrovirtel]] data archive {{Obscode|I03}}, in August 2000, less than 5 months prior to its official discovery observation at Socorro. === Close approaches === {{mp|2001 AV|43}} has an ''Earth [[minimum orbital intersection distance]]'' of {{convert |0.0017 |AU |km |abbr=on |lk=off |sigfig=3}}, which translates into 0.7 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|lunar distances]] (LD). Due to its small size, that is, an [[absolute magnitude]] fainter than 22, this asteroid is not classified as a [[potentially hazardous asteroid]]. On 18 November 2013, the asteroid passed Earth at 2.7 LD. The angle of approach made it a good target for radar observations. On 11 November 2029, the orbit of {{mp|2001 AV|43}} is predicted to bring the asteroid within a nominal distance of {{convert |0.00209 |AU |km mi |abbr=on |lk=off}} or 0.81 LD of Earth. It will also pass the [[Moon]] at an even shorter nominal distance of {{convert |0.00166 |AU |km mi |abbr=on |lk=off}} ==Physical characteristics== {{mp|2001 AV|43}} is an assumed stony [[S-type asteroid]]. === Rotation period === A rotational [[lightcurve]] of {{mp|2001 AV|43}} was obtained from photometric observations by American astronomers [[Robert J. Whiteley]], [[Carl Hergenrother]] and [[David Tholen]]. Lightcurve analysis gave a [[rotation period]] of 0.1701 hours (612 second) with a brightness amplitude of 0.26 [[Magnitude (astronomy)|magnitude]] ({{small|[[LCDB quality code|U=2]]}}). With such a short period, it is a notable [[List of fast rotators (minor planets)|fast rotator]]. The observers classified it as a "monolithic fast-rotating asteroid" (MFRA). === Diameter and albedo === The ''Collaborative Asteroid Lightcurve Link'' assumes a standard albedo for stony asteroids of 0.20 and derives a diameter of 0.03 kilometers based on an absolute magnitude of 24.9. == Numbering and naming == As of 2018, this [[minor planet]] has neither been numbered nor [[List of named minor planets (alphabetical)|named]]. == References == {{reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web |type = 2013-11-24 last obs. |title = JPL Small-Body Database Browser: (2001 AV43) |url = https://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=3067828 |publisher = [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate = 2 November 2018}} {{cite web |title = 2001 AV43 |work = Minor Planet Center |url = https://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?object_id=2001+AV43 |accessdate = 2 November 2018}} {{cite news |author = Jim Borg |title = Asteroid to make 'close' pass to Earth on Monday |url = http://www.staradvertiser.com/2013/11/16/breaking-news/asteroid-to-make-close-pass-to-earth-on-monday/ |publisher = Star Advertiser |date = 16 November 2013}} {{cite web |title = LCDB Data for 2001 AV43 |publisher = Asteroid Lightcurve Database (LCDB) |url = http://www.minorplanet.info/PHP/GenerateALCDEFPage_Local.php?AstInfo=0%7C2001+AV43 |accessdate = 24 January 2018}} {{Cite journal |first1 = R. J. |last1 = Whiteley |first2 = C. W. |last2 = Hergenrother |first3 = D. J. |last3 = Tholen |date = November 2002 |title = Monolithic fast-rotating asteroids |url = http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/bib_query?bibcode=2002ESASP.500..473W |journal = Proceedings of Asteroids |pages = 473–480 |bibcode = 2002ESASP.500..473W |access-date= 24 January 2018}} }} == External links == * [http://www.brera.mi.astro.it/sormano/teca.html Table of Asteroids Next Closest Approaches to the Earth], ''[[Sormano Astronomical Observatory]]'' * [http://www.minorplanet.info/PHP/lcdbsummaryquery.php Asteroid Lightcurve Database (LCDB)], query form ([http://www.minorplanet.info/lightcurvedatabase.html info]) * [http://obswww.unige.ch/~behrend/page_cou.html Asteroids and comets rotation curves, CdR] – Observatoire de Genève, Raoul Behrend * [https://www.minorplanetcenter.net/iau/lists/CloseApp.html Forthcoming Close Approaches To The Earth] – Minor Planet Center * {{NeoDys|2001AV43}} * {{JPL small body}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Small Solar System bodies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2001 AV43}} [[Category:Apollo asteroids|#]] [[Category:Unnumbered minor planets]] [[Category:Radar-imaged asteroids|#]] [[Category:Near-Earth objects in 2013]] [[Category:Astronomical objects discovered in 2001|20010105]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{semiprotected|small=yes}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = 6ix9ine | image = 6ix9ine June 2018 (cropped).jpg | image_size = 175 | alt = | caption = 6ix9ine performing in 2018. | birth_name = Daniel Hernandez | alias = {{ubl|Tekashi69<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/8214817/6ix9ine-controversy-timeline |title=A Timeline of 6ix9ine's Controversial Beefs, Behavior & Canceled Shows |work=Billboard |date=February 23, 2018 |accessdate=August 3, 2018}}</ref>}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1996|5|8}} | birth_place = [[Bushwick, Brooklyn|Bushwick]], [[Brooklyn]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | occupation = {{flatlist| * Rapper * songwriter<!--Please do not add to this list without first discussing your proposal on the talk page. --> }} | years_active = 2014–2018<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=76jDW99bHIY 6ix9ine - "ScumLife" (Official Music Video) - YouTube<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[https://genius.com/albums/6ix9ine/Scummy-scumz 6ix9ine - SCUMMY SCUMZ Lyrics and Tracklist | Genius<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> | background = solo_singer | instrument = Vocals | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] * [[Soundcloud rap]]<ref name="vulturexplained">{{cite web |url=http://www.vulture.com/2018/03/xxxtentacion-no-1-album-explained.html |author=Frank Guan |date=March 28, 2018 |title=SoundCloud Rap Has Its First No. 1 Album — Now What? |work=Vulture}}</ref><ref name="Caramanica">{{cite news |author=Jon Caramanica |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/21/arts/music/xxxtentacion-question-6ix9ine-day69-review.html |title=Two SoundCloud Rap Outlaws Push Boundaries From the Fringes |work=The New York Times |date=March 21, 2018}}</ref> }} | label = {{flatlist| * [[ScumGang Records|ScumGang]] * [[Tr3yway]] * TenThousand Projects }} | associated_acts = {{flatlist| * [[Nicki Minaj]] * [[Swizz Beatz]] * Trife Drew * [[Trippie Redd]] * [[City Morgue|ZillaKami]] }} | website = {{URL|6ix9ineshop.com}} }} '''Daniel Hernandez''' (born May 8, 1996), known professionally as '''6ix9ine''' (pronounced "six nine") or '''Tekashi69''', is an American rapper and Internet personality. Hernandez is known for his distinctive [[rainbow]]-themed look, [[Hardcore hip hop|aggressive]] style of rapping, public feuds with fellow celebrities, legal issues, and controversial public persona. All 10 of his singles have charted on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].<ref name=":10">{{Cite news|url=https://www.hotnewhiphop.com/6ix9ine-celebrates-stoopid-going-10-for-10-on-billboard-while-heading-to-court-news.62336.html|title=6ix9ine Celebrates "Stoopid" Going 10 For 10 On Billboard While Heading To Court|work=HotNewHipHop|access-date=2018-11-27}}</ref>
Hernandez rose to mainstream fame in late 2017 with the release of his debut single "[[Gummo (song)|Gummo]]", which was certified [[Music certification|platinum]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]]. In early 2018, Hernandez released his debut mixtape, ''[[Day69]]'', which debuted at number 4 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] album chart. He later earned his first top-five entry on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 with "[[Fefe (song)|Fefe]]", featuring [[Nicki Minaj]] and [[Murda Beatz]], which peaked at number three on the chart. His debut studio album, ''[[Dummy Boy]]'', was released on November 27, 2018, after being delayed a week earlier due to his arrest.<ref name=":92">{{Cite news|url=https://www.hotnewhiphop.com/stream-tekashi-6ix9ines-new-album-dummy-boy-news.65484.html|title=Stream Tekashi 6ix9ine's New Album "DUMMY BOY"|work=HotNewHipHop|access-date=2018-11-27}}</ref>
Hernandez pled guilty to using a 13-year-old child in a sexual performance in 2015. He was [[Trial of 6ix9ine|arrested in November 2018]] on [[Racket (crime)|racketeering]] and firearm charges, among others, for which he is facing a possible [[Life imprisonment|life sentence]] in prison.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/cmalone/2018/11/19/tekashi-6ix9ine-arrested-on-racketeering-weapons-charges/#6316e22466a8|title=Rapper 6ix9ine jailed on racketeering and weapon charges|date=November 23, 2018|publisher=[[Forbes]]}}</ref>
== Early life == Daniel Hernandez was born on May 8, 1996 in [[Bushwick, Brooklyn|Bushwick]], [[Brooklyn]], [[New York City]] to a mother originally from [[Atlixco]], [[Puebla]], [[Mexico]] and a [[Puerto Ricans|Puerto Rican]] father.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tidal.com/browse/track/84096476|title=Fat Joe and 6ix9ine interview presented by CocaVision and Tidal|publisher=[[Tidal (service)|Tidal]]|date=February 2018}}</ref>
He was raised with his older brother by his parents until he was 13, when his father was shot dead steps away from the family home.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qMt46dmSuxY "Open Space: Tekashi69 - YouTube"]. Interview with Mass Appeal, published August 3, 2017. See minute 4:09.</ref> Emotionally disturbed by the passing of his father, Hernandez started to act out and was eventually expelled from school in the 8th grade for bad behavior.<ref name="No Jumper">[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nIfXo2SbruU "The 6IX9INE Interview - YouTube"]. Interview with No Jumper, published July 24, 2017. See minutes 20:34–22:32.</ref> Rather than continue his education, he started working various odd jobs such as working as a busboy to help his mother financially. Hernandez also dealt drugs to supplement his income, most notably selling [[Cannabis (drug)|cannabis]] and [[heroin]] on the streets while working at a local Brooklyn [[convenience store|bodega]]. He was eventually arrested for his criminal activities and sentenced to prison time at [[Rikers Island]], where he began to associate himself with the [[Nine Trey Gangsters]], a prison subset of the [[Bloods]] street gang. Hernandez began his career as a rapper in 2014, releasing songs such as "69" and "Scumlife". Other early songs were taken down by [[YouTube]].<ref name="No Jumper" />
== Music career == ===2014–2016: Early career=== Hernandez began releasing rap songs in 2014. Over the next three years, he released multiple tracks and videos with titles such as "Scumlife", "Yokai", and "Hellsing Station", drawing attention for his aggressive rapping style and use of [[anime]] as music video visuals. Many of his early songs were released by FCK THEM, a music label based in [[Slovakia]].<ref name="69early">{{cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2018/02/how-fast-can-6ix9ine-paint-himself-into-a-corner.html|title=How Fast Can 6ix9ine Paint Himself Into a Corner?|website=Vulture|author=Frank Guan|date=February 23, 2018|accessdate=May 27, 2018}}</ref> Gathering fame as an internet meme for his rainbow-dyed hair and rainbow-plated [[Grill (jewelry)|grills]], he eventually became an associate of fellow New York rapper [[ZillaKami]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theringer.com/2018/3/1/17067584/6ix9ine-tekashi-gummo-rap-controversy|title=Meet 6ix9ine: The First Rap Star of 2018 Is Easy to Hate, Impossible to Ignore|work=The Ringer|access-date=August 7, 2018}}</ref> They later feuded after Hernandez allegedly stole instrumentals and songs they had made together.<ref>{{Citation|last=No Jumper|title=The ZillaKami & SosMula Interview|date=July 8, 2018|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c3LPT06_0Is&t=914s|access-date=August 7, 2018}}</ref>
"Poles1469", released in April 2017, featured Hernandez alongside [[Ohio]]-based artist [[Trippie Redd]] and was the first of Hernandez's songs to receive significant views on [[YouTube]].<ref name="69early" />
===2017–present: Breakthrough and ''Day69''=== Hernandez rose to prominence on social media due to a July 2017 [[Instagram]] post that went viral on both Reddit and Twitter. Hernandez's eccentric appearance (rainbow-dyed hair, a rainbow [[Grill (jewelry)|grill]], and multiple versions of the number 69 tattooed on his body) turned him into an [[internet meme]].<ref name="Genius">{{Cite web|url=https://genius.com/a/here-s-what-you-need-to-know-about-controversial-brooklyn-rapper-6ix9ine-his-breakout-hit-gummo|title=Here’s What You Need To Know About Controversial Brooklyn Rapper 6ix9ine & His Breakout Hit 'Gummo'|date=November 15, 2017|website=Genius|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171228214844/https://genius.com/a/here-s-what-you-need-to-know-about-controversial-brooklyn-rapper-6ix9ine-his-breakout-hit-gummo|archivedate=December 28, 2017|deadurl=no|access-date=December 8, 2017}}</ref>
Hernandez's commercial debut single "[[Gummo (song)|Gummo]]" was released on November 10, 2017, and eventually peaked at number 12 on the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/gummo-mw0003125113 |title=GUMMO - 6ix9ine {{!}} Songs, Reviews, Credits {{!}} AllMusic |accessdate=December 8, 2017}}</ref><ref>[https://www.billboard.com/charts/hot-100/2017-12-30 "Billboard Hot 100: December 30, 2017"]. ''Billboard''.</ref> It was certified platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]] on March 5, 2018.<ref name="riaa">{{cite web|url=https://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/?tab_active=default-award&se=6ix9ine#search_section|title=Gold & Platinum: 6ix9ine - RIAA|publisher=Recording Industry Association of America |access-date=August 15, 2018}}</ref> His next single, "[[Kooda]]", debuted at number 61 on the Hot 100 the week of December 23, 2017.<ref>[https://www.billboard.com/charts/hot-100/2017-12-23 "Billboard Hot 100: December 23, 2017"]. ''Billboard''.</ref> On January 14, 2018, Hernandez released his third single, "[[Keke (song)|Keke]]", with [[Fetty Wap]] and [[A Boogie wit da Hoodie]], which also charted on the Hot 100.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.xxlmag.com/rap-music/new-music/2018/01/6ix9ine-fetty-wap-a-boogie-wit-da-hoodie-keke-video/ |title=6ix9ine Drops New ''KeKe'' Video |website=XXL |date=January 14, 2018 |access-date=January 30, 2018}}</ref>
Shortly afterward, Hernandez announced his debut mixtape, titled ''[[Day69]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2018/01/6ix9ine-debut-project-release-date/ |title=6ix9ine Shares Release Date for His Debut Mixtape |website=XXL |date=January 29, 2018 |access-date=January 30, 2018}}</ref> The mixtape was released on February 23, 2018, and debuted at number 4 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] album chart with 55,000 [[album-equivalent unit]]s, of which 20,000 were pure sales.<ref name="Day69">{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/rap-music/new-music/2018/02/6ix9ine-day69/|title=6ix9ine Drops Debut Mixtape 'Day69'|date=February 23, 2018|website=XXL|accessdate=February 23, 2018}}</ref><ref name="BB debut">{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/8230391/bon-jovis-back-at-no-1-on-billboard-200-albums-chart|title=Bon Jovi's Back at No. 1 on Billboard 200 Albums Chart|work=Billboard|last=Caulfield|first=Keith|date=March 4, 2018|accessdate=March 5, 2018}}</ref> According to Jon Caramanica of ''[[The New York Times]]'', the tape was an outgrowth of the "[[SoundCloud rap]] explosion", and was notable for its willingness to deviate from hip-hop's prevailing sound.<ref name="Caramanica" /> After the release of ''Day69'', two songs from the album, "Billy" and "Rondo" both debuted on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100, with "Billy" peaking at number 50 and "Rondo" at number 73.<ref name="auto">{{Cite news|url=https://www.hotnewhiphop.com/tekashi-6ix9ine-makes-his-sixth-consecutive-hot-100-entry-with-gotti-news.48564.html|title=Tekashi 6ix9ine Scores Sixth Consecutive Hot 100 Entry With "Gotti"|work=HotNewHipHop|access-date=August 7, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://headlineplanet.com/home/2018/03/06/6ix9ines-billy-rondo-debut-billboard-hot-100/|title=6ix9ine’s "Billy," "Rondo" Debut On Billboard Hot 100|date=March 6, 2018|work=Headline Planet|access-date=August 7, 2018}}</ref>
In April 2018, Hernandez released "[[Gotti (song)|Gotti]]", a remix of a feature he did for artist Packman titled "Got it, Got it".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thebeatdfw.com/3037783/new-music-6ix9ine-got-it-got-it-feat-packman-explicit-audio/|title=New Music: 6ix9ine "Got It, Got It" Feat. Packman (Explicit Audio)|date=January 29, 2018|work=97.9 The Beat|access-date=August 7, 2018}}</ref> The song's video was released on April 16, 2018, and involved Hernandez donating bundles of $100 bills to poor citizens in the [[Dominican Republic]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/8301718/6ix9ine-new-song-gotti-listen|title=6ix9ine Shows Off His Melodic Side on New Song 'Gotti': Listen|work=Billboard|access-date=August 7, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/8342315/6ix9ine-gotti-video|title=6ix9ine Gives Back to the Community in New 'Gotti' Video: Watch|work=Billboard|access-date=August 7, 2018}}</ref> The song was added to ''Day69'' as a deluxe song and debuted at number 99 on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 before dropping off the following week, making it his sixth consecutive Hot 100 entry.<ref name="auto"/>
Hernandez stirred up controversy in May 2018 when he was involved in a shooting with the entourage of fellow New York rapper [[Casanova (rapper)|Casanova]] as part of a feud; this led to Hernandez losing a $5 million headphone deal and being banned from the [[Barclays Center]].<ref name="auto1">{{Cite news|url=https://hiphopdx.com/news/id.46742/title.alleged-tekashi-6ix9ine-affiliate-arrested-over-barclays-shooting#|title=Alleged Tekashi 6ix9ine Affiliate Arrested Over Barclays Shooting|last=http://hiphopdx.com|first=HipHopDX -|work=HipHopDX|access-date=August 7, 2018}}</ref> After the shooting, Hernandez stopped releasing music for several months, before releasing "[[Tati (song)|Tati]]", featuring DJ Spinking in June, which debuted at number 43 on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100.<ref name="auto1"/>
In July 2018, Hernandez released his eighth single, "[[Fefe (song)|Fefe]]", featuring [[Nicki Minaj]] and [[Murda Beatz]]; the single debuted at number four on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 before peaking at number three in its second week, marking 6ix9ine's highest entry on the chart and his first single to reach the top five of the Hot 100.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/8468763/drake-in-my-feelings-hot-100|title=Drake Dominates Hot 100 for Fourth Week With 'In My Feelings,' DJ Khaled's All-Star 'No Brainer' Debuts at No. 5|work=Billboard|access-date=August 7, 2018}}</ref> "Fefe" was later certified double [[Music recording certification|platinum]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]].<ref name=":02">{{Cite news|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2018/08/6ix9ine-fefe-platinum-nicki-minaj-murda-beatz/|title=6ix9ine’s “Fefe” Featuring Nicki Minaj, Murda Beatz Goes Platinum - XXL|work=XXL Mag|access-date=2018-08-27|language=en}}</ref> His subsequent singles, "Bebe" and "Stoopid", also proved successful and both reached the top 30 of the Hot 100.<ref name=":10" />
In early October 2018, Hernandez was featured on the song "Aulos Reloaded" with French house DJ Vladimir Cauchemar and "Kick" with Danish singer [[Jimilian]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.hotnewhiphop.com/6ix9ine-is-the-reigning-king-of-europe-on-vladimir-cauchemars-aulos-reloaded-new-song.1980490.html |title=6ix9ine Is The Reigning King Of Europe On Vladimir Cauchemar's "Aulos Reloaded" |website=HotNewHipHop |access-date=October 5, 2018}}</ref>
On November 7, 2018, it was announced that his debut studio album, ''[[Dummy Boy]]'', was to be released on November 23,<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2018/11/6ix9ine-dummy-boy-release-date-cover-art/ |title=6ix9ine Unveils Release Date and Cover Art for New Project |website=XXL |access-date=November 7, 2018}}</ref> but on November 21, it was announced that the album would be postponed.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/Bqcxy3mgdPO/|title=Instagram post by @akadmiks • November 21, 2018 at 12:30pm UTC|website=Instagram|access-date=November 21, 2018}}</ref> The album was ultimately released without notice on November 27, on all streaming services.<ref name=":9">{{Cite news|url=https://www.hotnewhiphop.com/stream-tekashi-6ix9ines-new-album-dummy-boy-news.65484.html|title=Stream Tekashi 6ix9ine's New Album "DUMMY BOY"|work=HotNewHipHop|access-date=2018-11-27}}</ref>
== Notable feuds == In April 2017, Hernandez and [[Trippie Redd]] released their first collaboration, "Poles1469", and in July 2017, they released another, "Owee."<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://massappeal.com/trippie-redd-tekashi69-beef-history/|title=A Brief History of the Trippie Redd and Tekashi 6ix9ine Beef|date=November 17, 2017|first=Andrew|last=Matson|publisher=Mass Appeal|accessdate=March 15, 2018}}</ref> Later that year, upon seeing a post from a Twitter account claiming Hernandez was a pedophile following the release of images and information by fellow rapper and 6ix9ine detractor [[ZillaKami]], Trippie Redd denounced Hernandez, saying, "I'm sorry brozay (sic), 1400 don't promote pedophiles... If we give niggas clout, we give niggas clout. It was an accident."<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://massappeal.com/trippie-redd-denounce-tekashi-6ix9ine/|title=Trippie Redd Denounces Tekashi 6ix9ine As A "Pedophile"|date=August 7, 2017|work=Mass Appeal|access-date=March 15, 2018}}</ref> On November 11, 2017, following a series of barbs the two traded on social media, Redd was attacked in the lobby of a New York hotel and blamed Hernandez and his crew in an [[Instagram]] live video.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.worldstarhiphop.com/videos/video.php?v=wshhxN5aHdXMytN6m3tq|title=Trippie Redd Claims Tekashi 6ix9ine And Crew Jumped Him At His Hotel In New York, Bans Tekashi From LA!|work=WORLDSTARHIPHOP|access-date=March 15, 2018}}</ref> Hernandez later insinuated his involvement in an Instagram live video, saying, "I don't know what's going on, but your chin is bruised up. You can't just be out here calling people gay, bro. Can't be supporting false accusations, you can't be ranting on Live talking about New York. Fuck these niggas talking about, New York this, New York that, like, you just can't do that bro. You should put some ice on that chin, it's bruised up. I feel bad bro... I just want you to be my friend again," before proceeding to sing the [[Hook (music)|hook]] from "Poles1469." He was referencing a post by Trippie Redd that showed Hernandez holding hands with another man with a caption insinuating Hernandez was gay.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://www.worldstarhiphop.com/videos/video.php?v=wshh8O1taL47T3o6M2N4|title=Tekashi 6ix9ine Responds To Trippie Redd Calling Him Gay & Ranting About Him On Instagram! "You Should Put Some Ice On That Chin, It's Bruised Up"|work=WORLDSTARHIPHOP|access-date=March 15, 2018}}</ref> In February 2018, Hernandez was assaulted by several men outside a Los Angeles airport shortly after arguing with Trippie Redd on Instagram. Their feud continued to escalate with mutual Internet trolling. Hernandez later accused Redd over Instagram Live of having pedophilic sexual relations with fellow rapper [[Danielle Bregoli|Danielle "Bhad Bhabie" Bregoli]], who was a minor at the time. Trippie Redd denied the allegations, and reiterated Hernandez's conviction for use of a child in sexual performance. Bregoli also took to Instagram Live to deny the claims, but admitted the two had kissed in the past, saying, "We kissed but it wasn't that serious and he was 17 at the time."<ref name=":8">{{Cite news|url=https://hiphopdx.com/news/id.46853/title.trippie-redd-bhad-bhabie-deny-tekashi-6ix9ines-claim-they-had-sex#|title=Trippie Redd & Bhad Bhabie Deny Tekashi 6ix9ine's Claim They Had Sex|work=HipHopDX|access-date=May 15, 2018}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/8213557/6ix9ine-lax-airport-fight|title=6ix9ine Involved in Brawl at Los Angeles Airport|work=Billboard|access-date=June 17, 2018}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/video/2018/02/video-6ix9ine-fight-lax/|title=6ix9ine Gets Into a Massive Brawl at LAX - XXL|website=XXL Mag|access-date=June 17, 2018}}</ref> After the dissolution of Redd’s relationship with his then-girlfriend Alexandria Laveglia,<ref> [https://www.last.fm/music/AYLEK$/+wiki Aylek$ Background Information Revealed] - Last.FM Reporting</ref> known professionally as Aylek$, Hernandez started posting videos of himself with her, hinting at sexual activity between the two, to the ignominy of Trippie Redd.<ref> [https://www.hotnewhiphop.com/tekashi-6ix9ine-taunts-trippie-redd-with-picture-of-his-ex-girlfriend-ayleks-news.58879.html?_amp 6ix9ine taunts Trippie Amid Breakup with Aylek$] - Hot New Hip Hop Reporting</ref><ref> [http://www.xxlmag.com/video/2018/11/6ix9ine-bed-with-trippie-redd-ex-girlfriend-ayleks/ 6ix9ine in bed with Trippie Redd ex-girlfriend Aylek$] - XXL Reporting</ref><ref> [http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2018/11/6ix9ine-claims-sex-trippie-redds-ex-girlfriend-ayleks/ 6ix9ine Claims to have had Relations with Aylek$] - XXL Reporting</ref> After Hernandez’s November 2018 federal arrest on [[RICO]] charges, Trippie Redd mocked Hernandez’s imprisonment in a video of him dancing to the tune of [[Akon]]'s 2004 hit single "[[Locked Up (song)|Locked Up]]", mimicking a jail scenario.<ref> [https://www.inquisitr.com/5171446/blac-chyna-trolls-tekashi-6ix9ine-50-cent-tells-the-jailed-rapper-to-lose-his-number/ Celebrity reactions 6ix9ine’s Federal Arrest] - Inquisitr Reporting</ref><ref> [https://www.vladtv.com/amp/249919/trippie-redd-mocks-tekashi-6ix9ine-getting-locked-up Trippie Redd trolls 6ix9ine following his Federal Arrest] - Inquisitr Reporting</ref>
Throughout 2018, Hernandez was involved in feuds with a number of [[Chicago]] [[Drill music|drill]] artists from the GloGang (Glory Boyz Entertainment) collective, including [[Chief Keef]], [[Lil Reese]], and Tadoe (Chief Keef's cousin), stemming from domestic abuse and relationship issues relating to fellow rapper Cuban Doll, who was in a romantic relationship with Tadoe but also friendly with Hernandez.<ref>{{cite web |title=Tekashi 6ix9ine Goes on a Troll Tour Across Chicago |url=http://thesource.com/2018/06/13/tekashi-6ix9ine-chicago/ |website=The Source |accessdate=July 24, 2018 |date=June 13, 2018}}</ref> The two continued to feud on social media, with Hernandez posting a video of his semi-romantic vacation to Hawaii with Cuban Doll to Instagram,<ref> [https://www.vladtv.com/amp/244688/cuban-doll-kicks-it-in-hawaii-with-tekashi-6ix9ine-after-tadoe-incident 6ix9ine shows off Cuban Doll amid Tadoe] - Vlad TV reports on 6ix9ine</ref> and driving up to Chief Keef’s old neighborhood and calling him out,<ref> [https://www.hotnewhiphop.com/tekashi-6ix9ine-continues-to-troll-chicago-and-pulls-up-to-englewood-news.52501.html?_amp 6ix9ine Escalates Feud With Chief Keef] - Hot New Hip Hop Report on 6ix9ine Beef</ref> as well as contacting the mother of one of Chief Keef’s sons and recording himself buying her designer clothes and verbally taunting him, and later receiving fellatio from her.<ref> [http://www.xxlmag.com/video/2018/06/6ix9ine-chief-keef-baby-mama-shopping-spree/ 6ix9ine takes Chief Keef babymama on Shopping Spree] - XXL Mag Reporting</ref><ref> [https://www.vladtv.com/amp/246630/chief-keefs-babymama-slim-danger-says-she-gave-tekashi-6ixnine-oral-sex Slim Danger admits to performing fellatio on 6ix9ine] - Vlad TV Reporting</ref> On May 8, 2018, [[Trippie Redd]] previewed the song "I Kill People" on [[Instagram]], featuring Chief Keef and Tadoe, which was aimed as a diss toward 6ix9ine and Cuban Doll.<ref> [https://genius.com/amp/Trippie-redd-i-kill-people-lyrics Trippie Redd joins GloGang’s Beef with 6ix9ine] - Decoding Lyrics</ref> On June 2, 2018, Chief Keef was fired upon outside the W Hotel in [[New York City]] but not hit; no injuries resulted from the incident.<ref>{{cite web |title=Chief Keef Shot at Outside New York City Hotel |url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2018/06/chief-keef-shot-at-outside-new-york-hotel/ |website=XXL |accessdate=July 24, 2018 |date=June 2, 2018}}</ref> Due to the ongoing feud, Hernandez was confirmed to be under investigation by the [[New York Police Department]] for possible involvement with the incident, despite being in [[Los Angeles]] at the time.<ref>{{cite web |title=6ix9ine Under Investigation for Involvement in Chief Keef NYC Shooting: Report |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/8461408/6ix9ine-under-investigation-chief-keef-shooting |website=Billboard |accessdate=July 23, 2018 |date=June 18, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.spin.com/2018/06/6ix9ine-under-investigation-in-attempted-shooting-of-chief-keef-report/ |title=6ix9ine Under Investigation in Attempted Shooting of Chief Keef: Report |author=Anna Gaca |date=June 18, 2018 |website=Spin |accessdate=June 19, 2018 |deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=https://hiphopdx.com/news/id.46764/title.trippie-redd-teases-tekashi-6ix9ine-diss-song-with-chief-keef-tadoe|title=Trippie Redd Teases Tekashi 6ix9ine Diss Song With Chief Keef & Tadoe|last=http://hiphopdx.com|first=HipHopDX -|work=HipHopDX|access-date=June 17, 2018}}</ref><ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=https://www.hotnewhiphop.com/trippie-redd-connects-with-chief-keef-and-tadoe-on-new-song-i-kill-people-new-song.1978870.html|title=Trippie Redd Connects With Chief Keef & Tadoe On New Song "I Kill People!"|work=HotNewHipHop|access-date=June 17, 2018}}</ref>
==Personal and legal issues == {{See also|Trial of 6ix9ine}} Hernandez has a daughter, Saraiyah (born March 20, 2013), with Sara Molina.<ref> [https://www.yahoo.com/amphtml/lifestyle/7-details-tekashi-6ix9ine-apos-141813829.html Who is 6ix9ine secretive baby mama?] - Yahoo Reporting</ref><ref> [https://pagesix.com/2018/07/23/bodyguards-camped-outside-home-of-tekashi-6ix9ines-baby-mama/amp/ 6ix9ine home life] - Page 6ix Reporting</ref> On the night of November 11, 2018, just days before his arrest on [[RICO]] charges, Hernandez allegedly struck Molina once in the face during an argument after being confronted about cheating on her. She questioned him after finding provocative text messages from Jade, a woman Hernandez was seeing. The incident left Molina with a bruised lip.<ref> [http://hyperap.com/6ix9ine-accused-of-beating-his-baby-mama-sara/ 6ix9ine Domestic Abuse Allegations Uncovered by DomIsLive News] - HypeRap Reporting</ref><ref> [https://mtonews.com/.amp/rapper-tekashi-6ix9ine-accused-of-beating-baby-mama-pics 6ix9ine Allegedly a Domestic Abuser] - MTO Reporting</ref>
Hernandez's criminal behavior has been the subject of controversy, most notably relating to a child sex case from 2015.<ref name="Caramanica" /><ref name="Legal1">{{Cite web|url=https://jezebel.com/details-in-child-sex-complaint-against-rapper-6ix9ine-c-1821245294|title=Details in Child Sex Complaint Against Rapper 6ix9ine Contradict His Public Comments|author=Rich Juzwiak|date=December 14, 2017|website=Jezebel|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180405180207/https://jezebel.com/details-in-child-sex-complaint-against-rapper-6ix9ine-c-1821245294|archivedate=April 5, 2018|deadurl=no|access-date=December 18, 2017}}</ref> In October 2015, Hernandez pled guilty to a felony count of use of a child in a sexual performance. He was charged with three counts of the offense after a February 2015 incident in which he had physical contact with a 13-year-old girl and later distributed videos of the incident online as part of a music video. Three videos are described in the criminal complaint against Hernandez. In the first, "the child engages in oral sexual intercourse with the separately charged defendant Taquan Anderson, while the defendant, Daniel Hernandez, stands behind the child making a thrusting motion with his pelvis and smacking her on her buttocks. The child is nude in the video." The other videos show the child sitting on Hernandez's lap while Anderson gropes her breasts, and later sitting naked across the laps of Anderson and Hernandez.<ref name="Legal1" />
In a November 2017 interview, Hernandez claimed to have had "no sexual contact" with the girl and denied knowing she was a minor. Hernandez also claimed to have been 17 at the time of the incident, though the birth date listed in the complaint against him and in his statement to the police shows he was 18.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2017/12/tekashi-6ix9ine-child-sex-complaint-details/ |title=New Details in Tekashi 6ix9ine's Sexual Misconduct Case |author=Nick Mojica |date=December 14, 2017 |website=XXL |accessdate=December 29, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180214025643/http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2017/12/tekashi-6ix9ine-child-sex-complaint-details/ |archivedate=February 14, 2018}}</ref>
Under his plea deal, Hernandez must obtain his [[General Education Development|GED]], refrain from posting sexually explicit or violent images of women or children to social media, and not commit another crime for two years, among other injunctions. If met, the plea deal will give Hernandez three years' probation and he will not have to register as a sex offender; if not, Hernandez could face up to three years in prison. In a January 2018 court hearing, it was revealed that Hernandez had failed his GED test, but had his sentencing adjourned until April 10, 2018.<ref>{{cite web |author=Nick Mojica |url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2018/01/6ix9ine-fails-ged-test/ |title=Judge Gives 6ix9ine One Last Chance to Pass GED Test |website=XXL |date=January 30, 2018 |accessdate=April 5, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180201222959/http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2018/01/6ix9ine-fails-ged-test/ |archivedate=February 1, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Rich Juzwiak |url=https://jezebel.com/sentencing-in-rapper-6ix9ines-child-sex-case-delayed-be-1822557621 |title=Sentencing in Rapper 6ix9ine's Child Sex Case Delayed Because He Failed His GED |work=Jezebel |date=January 30, 2018 |accessdate=April 5, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180201022908/https://jezebel.com/sentencing-in-rapper-6ix9ines-child-sex-case-delayed-be-1822557621 |archivedate=February 1, 2018}}</ref> The court date was later postponed, reportedly because the court did not have a copy of Hernandez's GED.<ref>{{cite web |author=Joshua Espinoza |title=6ix9ine's Court Date in Child Sex Case Postponed |url=https://www.complex.com/music/2018/04/tekashi-6ix9ine-court-date-postponed-deletes-instagram-posts-drops-gotti-track |website=Complex |accessdate=June 9, 2018 |date=April 10, 2018}}</ref> Prior to his sexual misconduct charges, Hernandez served jail time as a minor for assault and the sale of heroin.<ref name="Genius" />
On July 12, 2018, Hernandez was arrested in New York for an outstanding warrant related to an incident where he allegedly choked a 16-year-old in [[Houston]]'s [[The Galleria|Galleria mall]] in January 2018.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Strauss |first1=Matthew |title=6ix9ine Arrested for Allegedly Choking 16-Year-Old |url=https://pitchfork.com/news/6ix9ine-arrested-for-allegedly-choking-16-year-old/ |website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]] |date=July 11, 2018 |accessdate=July 12, 2018}}</ref>
In the early morning hours of July 22, 2018, Hernandez was kidnapped, beaten, and robbed by three armed assailants in Brooklyn. He had finished shooting the music video for "FEFE" (featuring [[Nicki Minaj]] and [[Murda Beatz]]) when the assailants grabbed him outside his home and pistol-whipped him. The robbers eventually took over $750,000 in custom jewelry and approximately $35,000 in cash. Hernandez escaped from their vehicle and summoned police help via a stranger. He was taken to the hospital.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tekashi 6ix9ine Kidnapped, Robbed and Hospitalized (Report)|url=https://variety.com/2018/music/news/tekashi-6ix9ine-kidnapped-robbed-hospitalized-1202880725/|work=Variety|date=July 22, 2018|accessdate=July 24, 2018}}</ref>
Due to his continuing legal problems in light of his plea bargain, the Manhattan district attorney's office announced Hernandez could face up to three years in prison and possible [[Sex offender registry#In the United States|sex offender registration]] for his 2015 case,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.spin.com/2018/08/6ix9ine-jail-sex-offender-sentencing/|title=6ix9ine Could Face Prison in 2015 Sexual Misconduct Case|date=August 9, 2018|publisher=}}</ref> but he was instead sentenced to four years' probation starting in October 2018, with one clause being that he cannot utter the phrase “[[Tr3yway|Treyway]]” in public as it was deemed to promote gang activity, as well as 1,000 hours of community service.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Klinkenberg |first1=Brendan |title=Tekashi 6ix9ine Sentenced to 4 Years Probation |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/tekashi-6ix9ine-probation-747879/ |accessdate=October 26, 2018 |work=Rolling Stone |date=October 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Moynihan |first1=Colin |title=Rapper 6ix9ine Sentenced to Probation in Sex Video Case |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/26/arts/tekashi-6ix9ine-sentencing-probation.html |accessdate=November 5, 2018 |work=New York Times |date=October 27, 2018}}</ref> On October 27, 2018, two members of Hernandez's entourage were involved in a shooting in [[Manhattan]] and were subsequently charged with gang assault.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Police Arrest 2 in Shooting Involving Rapper Tekashi69 |url=https://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/Police-Arrest-2-in-Shooting-Involving-Rapper-Tekashi69-498791211.html |work=NBC New York |agency=Associated Press |date=October 27, 2018 |access-date=November 5, 2018}}</ref>
On November 10, 2018, [[TMZ]] released surveillance footage of two men opening fire at the set of Hernandez's as well as [[Kanye West]] and [[Nicki Minaj]]'s music video shoot in [[Beverly Hills, California]].<ref>[http://www.tmz.com/2018/11/10/tekashi69-surveillance-video-gunmen-shooting-kanye-west-music-video/ Surveillance Footage Shows Gunmen Firing at Tekashi69, Kanye West Music Video Shoot | TMZ.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
On November 18, 2018, Hernandez, his former manager Kifano "Shotti" Jordan, and three other associates were arrested. Hernandez is charged with federal [[Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act|RICO]] and firearms charges, including conspiracy to murder and armed robbery, and faces up to life in prison. He is allegedly part of "a violent sect of the [[Bloods]]" known as the [[Nine Trey Gangsters]].<ref name="Brooklyn Rapper Tekashi 6ix9ine Arrested On Federal Racketeering Charges">{{cite web |title=Brooklyn Rapper Tekashi 6ix9ine Arrested On Federal Racketeering Charges |url=https://huffpost.com/us/entry/us_5bf2d912e4b0b84243e4a63d |website=Huffington Post|publisher=Huffington Post |accessdate= November 19, 2018}}</ref><ref name="racketeering" /><ref>{{cite news |last1=Beaumont-Thomas |first1=Ben |title=Rapper 6ix9ine arrested on robbery, racketeering and firearms charges |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/nov/20/rapper-6ix9ine-arrested-robbery-racketeering-firearms-charges-daniel-hernandez |accessdate=November 20, 2018 |work=The Guardian |date=November 20, 2018 |language=en}}</ref> Hernandez’s attorney, Lance Lazzaro, advocated for bail for his client on the condition that Hernandez surrender his passport, pay a little under $2 million for bail, and be placed under house arrest, but the judge denied bail, keeping Hernandez in custody on the grounds that he may still be a danger to the community even if those bail conditions were met. Hernandez’s legal team plans to appeal that decision. He was held at the [[Metropolitan Detention Center, Brooklyn|Metropolitan Detention Center]] in Brooklyn under [[Prison#Control units|general population]] before being moved to another facility due to security reasons, as Hernandez had multiple altercations with rival gang members [[The Crips]]. <ref name="racketeering" >{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/tekashi-6ix9ine-racketeering-and-firearm-charges-758516/|title=Tekashi 6ix9ine Faces 32 Years to Life in Prison on Racketeering, Firearm Charges|last=Klinkenberg|first=Brendan|date=November 20, 2018|work=Rolling Stone|access-date=November 20, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Discography== {{Main|6ix9ine discography}}

==Tours== * World Domination Tour (2018)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2018/06/6ix9ine-world-domination-tour-dates/|title=6ix9ine Shares World Domination Tour Dates - XXL|website=XXL Mag}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=6ix9ine Performs in Underwear During Show in France - XXL |url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2018/07/6ix9ine-performs-underwear/ |website=XXL Mag |accessdate=November 21, 2018 |language=en}}</ref>

{{for|the British motorcycle racer|Bill Ivy}} {{Other uses|Bill Ivy (disambiguation)}} '''Bill Ivy''' (born 1953 in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]]) is a veteran [[photographer]] and author on natural history, with 24 books to his credit including the award-winning ''A Little Wilderness: The Natural History of Toronto''.
In the mid-1960s he was a student at the [[International School Ibadan]] in [[Nigeria]] during the [[Nigerian Civil War]].
Ivy is a lecturer on photography and natural history, and a popular nature guide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.umanitoba.ca/cm/cmarchive/vol19no3/closetohome.html|publisher=University of Manitoba|title=Close to Home: A Canadian Country Diary|author=Young Canada Works}}</ref> He has appeared on numerous radio and TV programs. He was still photographer for the [[BBC]] on [[David Attenborough|Sir David Attenborough]]'s ''Wildlife on One: Backyard Bandits''. His work has been featured in hundreds of publications in North America and abroad.
He currently resides in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]].<ref>{{cite book|publisher=The International School, Ibadan|title=The Year Book|year=2001}}</ref>
== Selected books ==
* ''A Little Wilderness - The Natural History of Toronto'' ({{ISBN|0195404211}}) * ''Close to Home - A Canadian Country Diary'' ({{ISBN|1895246113}}) * ''Wildlife of America'' ({{ISBN|0831755814}}) * ''Wilderness Canada'' ({{ISBN|088665484X}}) * ''Getting to Know Nature's Children'' series * ''Our Wildlife World'' series
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * Bill Ivy's official site (http://www.billivy.com)

{{Italic title}}
[[File:Film and Photography during the Second World War SE6792.jpg|thumb|A ''Calling Blighty'' film unit sets up a shot with the dance band of the Cameronians in Singapore 21 February 1946. On the right of the camera is the producer, Captain L Hamilton-Webb, while around the microphone are Staff Captain Jackson and brothers Louis and Ted De Rosa.]]
Produced by the Directorate for Army Welfare (DAK) in [[British Raj|India]] from 1944 to 46, '''''Calling Blighty''''' was a series of ten-minute films which featured members of the [[British Armed Forces]] stationed in India and [[Southeast Asia]] speaking a personal message direct to camera. These films were shown back in the UK to a specially invited audience in a cinema in the area from which those featured came.
== Background == Poor welfare and especially length of tour duty, crystallised in the phrase "the Forgotten Army", led the [[War Office]] to investigate the significant issue of morale, which culminated in a tour of [[South East Asia Command]] (SEAC) by the [[Geoffrey FitzClarence, 5th Earl of Munster|Earl of Munster]] and his subsequent report in September 1944, although a Morale Committee had met regularly in the War Office since 1942.<ref name="sargent1992">Sargent, Paul. November 1992, "'Keep Smiling. Keep those chins up and God bless': filmed messages home from service personnel in the Far East during the Second World War." ''Imperial War Museum Review No. 7''.</ref> ''Calling Blighty'' was one of the steps introduced by the War Office to address concerns of low morale within the 14th Army stationed in India and SEAC during the latter stages of the [[Second World War]].<ref name="sargent1992"/>
The series title was probably derived from a [[Pathé News|Pathé Gazette]] newsreel issue of early 1944 featuring soldiers based in Italy and the first DAK ''Calling Blighty'' was issued in April 1944.<ref name="sargent1992"/> The production was based at what was then the Training Film Centre in [[Bombay]], already a film production centre for the making of training films for the [[British Indian Army|Indian Army]], (and later to become the Combined Kinematograph Services Film Production and Training Centre – CKS), with studio space rented at the Shree Sound Studios.<ref>Dawson, Adam. Sound Archives 1991, Imperial War Museum ref 12358. Mr Dawson worked both as a director and supervising film editor at the CKS.</ref>
''Calling Blighty'' was produced in two different formats: one was studio-based and the other shot on location. In the studio a canteen set was built to provide a realistic and relaxing environment and personnel were brought in to deliver their messages. On location the unit had to find the personnel – and they travelled widely, through India, [[British rule in Burma|Burma]] and [[British Malaya|Malaya]] – whom they filmed outside, usually with some significant landmark behind them. The format was similar to the canteen set-up, with each person addressing their loved ones with a short message direct to camera.<ref name="atcheler1991">Atcheler, Jack. Sound Archives 1991, Imperial War Museum ref 12357 Mr Atcheler was a cameraman on the ''Calling Blighty'' location unit.</ref>
The equipment used by both studio and location units was broadly the same; 35mm camera, film and sound equipment. In 1945 the cumbersome separate sound camera was replaced by a sound-on-film camera similar to those used for newsreels. The studio had a permanent complement of staff consisting of Indian as well as British personnel. The location unit usually comprised a director, two cameramen, two sound recordists, two assistants and a welfare officer responsible for making the contacts. At least one of the location units operated as part of the [[Army Kinematograph Service]] (AKS) and had been sent out from the [[UK]] to assist.<ref name="sargent1992"/>{{rp|33}}<ref name="atcheler1991"/><ref>The Indian documentary maker NS Thapa was a studio-based cameraman on ''Calling Blighty''.</ref>
Generally, people from one particular city, town or region were grouped together in order to facilitate screening back in the UK, and while personnel from all three services are featured, they are predominantly from the army.<ref name="sargent1992"/> The completed negatives were sent by sea to the UK, a journey of about six weeks. On arrival the negative was sent to [[Denham Film Studios|Denham Studios]] near [[Uxbridge]], [[Middlesex]], where a print was made for distribution, although a copy was kept in Bombay as a precaution against the negative being lost.<ref name="sargent1992"/><ref>Becket, Albert. Sound Archives 1991, Imperial War Museum ref 12356. Mr Becket was Production Manager at the CKS from May 1945 until August 1946</ref>
Each ''Calling Blighty'' screening took place at a cinema in the subjects local area and was usually organised by the regional Army Welfare Committee. The names and addresses of those to be invited were sent to the UK along with the films.<ref name="sargent1992"/>
These films continued to be produced after the [[surrender of Japan]] in August 1945 as many thousands of service personnel were still needed in SEAC; transport and forces were still required for the occupation of Malaya, [[Java]] and the return of thousands of prisoners of war, as well as for the occupation of Japan. Production of ''Calling Blighty'' finally ceased in April 1946.<ref name="sargent1992"/>
It is estimated that only slightly more than 10% of the ''Calling Blighty'' films have survived - some 52 issues.<ref name="sargent1992"/> It is estimated some 400 issues were produced, the majority of the originals – 47 – are held by the [[Imperial War Museum]] Film Archive. An additional five are held by the [[British Film Institute]] National Film Archive. Copies of all Manchester issues are held by the North West Film Archive at [[Manchester Metropolitan University]] who are running a project to trace all family members.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nwfa.mmu.ac.uk/blighty/index.php |title=Messages Home: Lost Films of the British Army |website=North West Film Archive |date=2016 |publisher=Manchester Metropolitan University |access-date=22 June 2016}}</ref> Individual copies relating to [[Norwich]] and [[Southampton]] are held by the relevant regional film archives.
